user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of request_completed_callback:
```c
static void
request_completed_callback (void *cls,
                            struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            void **req_cls,
                            enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode toe)
{
  struct Request *request = *req_cls;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) toe;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (NULL == request)
    return;
  if (NULL != request->session)
    request->session->rc--;
  if (NULL != request->pp)
    MHD_destroy_post_processor (request->pp);
  free (request);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function request_completed_callback:
struct Request
{

  /**
   * Associated session.
   */
  struct Session *session;

  /**
   * Post processor handling form data (IF this is
   * a POST request).
   */
  struct MHD_PostProcessor *pp;

  /**
   * URL to serve in response to this POST (if this request
   * was a 'POST')
   */
  const char *post_url;

}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (NULL != request->pp)
    MHD_destroy_post_processor (request->pp);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The code does not modify any function parameter variables. It dereferences the pointer parameter req_cls to obtain a local pointer (request) and then operates on and frees the object pointed to by that pointer; modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted by Rule 17.8, only the pointer parameter itself must not be assigned to. The fragment MHD_destroy_post_processor(request->pp) and free(request) modify the pointed-to objects, not the parameter variables, so no Rule 17.8 violation occurs.
